An excellent classic of its genre -- the hard-boiled detective novel.  If you have really been through the wringer with all of "today's" books and want to take yourself back to a simpler, better, more defined time, then "The Big Sleep" is a very good novel with which to begin.  It is not long and reads very quickly.  For all of us who have always wondered where the parodies and satires and even serious depictions of private eyes have come from, this is where it all started.

Raymond Chandler is a master at evoking setting and character with sharp, powerful prose.  He should be read by every reader who appreciates the genre of detective fiction, and studied by every serious writer, no matter the genre. His private eye, Philip Marlowe, is iconic, but his treatment of women leaves much to be desired.  Just keep in mind, he's a product of his era (The Thirties).
a classic that doesnt dissapoint. named my cat marlowe.

I love the Bogart/Bacall screen version, but the novel has a complete (though challenging) plot. In the book, you’ll finally find out what happened to “Shawn” (Rusty) Regan, Bacall’s husband. Little sister, Carmen, has a much more dominant role, and Geiger’s backstory business is much steamier than hinted at in the film.When Marlowe finally meets “Mrs. Eddie Mars,” Carmen’s sister (Bacall) isn’t there ... and the dynamic is much more suspenseful. Although I love THE BIG SLEEP, I actually think that two of Chandler’s less popular works are his triumphs: THE HIGH WINDOW and PLAYBACK.In short, even if you’ve seen the 1940s film adaptation dozens of times and have memorized the plot, you will find THE BIG SLEEP a very satisfying read.

summary:
When a dying millionaire hires Philip Marlowe to handle the blackmailer of one of his two troublesome daughters, Marlowe finds himself involved with more than extortion. Kidnapping, pornography, seduction, and murder are just a few of the complications he gets caught up in.

"Chandler [writes] like a slumming angel and invest[s] the sun-blinded streets of Los Angelos with a romantic presence."
